course_title: Special Topics in History: Japan and the World 1600-1900
class_notes:
Instructor is new history faculty Prof. Laura Nenzi.


Textbook narratives of Japanese history between 1600 and 1900 tell the story of a "closed country" that was eventually opened by the intervention of US Commodore Perry in 1854 and went on to westernize in the modern era. Textbook narratives are wrong. This reading seminar examines the place of Japan in the world, and of the outside world in Japan, between 1600 and 1900. We will consider formal and informal diplomacy, intellectual exchanges, commerce, curiosity, contact spaces, and the issue of "westernization." The assigned readings combine "classics" and recent scholarship. Japanese language skills and previous knowledge of Japanese history are welcome but not required.
